misconceptions.name: Program solves a different problem than specified (average acceleration instead of sum of even numbers)
misconceptions.description: The submitted program computes average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of reading 5 integers and summing only the even ones. It does not read 5 integers, does not use a loop, and does not perform any even-number filtering.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the task is to calculate the average acceleration given initial velocity v0, final velocity v1, and time t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, use a loop to process those inputs, add only the even numbers to a running sum, and then print the sum of the even numbers.
symptoms: Prompt text asks for v0, v1, and t instead of 5 integers
Program reads 3 double values instead of 5 integers
No loop is present to process 5 inputs
No conditional check using modulo (n % 2 == 0)
Output message reports average acceleration, not sum of even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between this assignment and a different example or problem about average acceleration, leading to reusing that solution instead of implementing the required sum-of-evens logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and design the program around its input-output requirements: prompt for 5 integers, use a loop to read each integer, check if each number is even with n % 2 == 0, accumulate the sum of even numbers, and then print the final sum.
related_concepts: Looping over a fixed number of inputs
Using modulo to test for even numbers
Designing appropriate input prompts and output messages
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (prompt, variable names, data types, formula, and output text) is focused on average acceleration and does not attempt to address reading 5 integers or summing even numbers.

evidence.note: Program prompts for v0, v1, and t, reads 3 doubles, and computes average acceleration instead of reading 5 integers and summing the even ones.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misinterpretation of Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate average acceleration using three inputs (v0, v1, t) instead of the required program to read five integers and calculate the sum of the even numbers among them. This indicates a complete failure to address the assignment prompt.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the assignment required them to implement an acceleration calculation based on three inputs (v0, v1, t).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required sequential reading of 5 integer inputs, iterating through them (or using 5 separate reads), applying a conditional check for evenness, and accumulating the sum of only the even numbers.
symptoms: Code calculates acceleration formula instead of summation logic
Prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of '5 integers'
Uses double data types instead of integers
Only 3 inputs are read instead of 5
No loop or repetition structure present
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have copied or submitted code for a different, unrelated assignment (likely an acceleration calculator) instead of the intended 'Sum of Even Numbers' problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please carefully review the problem description for 'Sum of Even Numbers' and implement the required logic: reading 5 integers, using a loop (or sequential reads), checking parity with the modulo operator (%), and using an accumulator variable.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is entirely unrelated to the prompt, evidenced by the variable names, input prompting, and calculation logic.

evidence.note: The prompt indicates solving the wrong problem, asking for velocity and time variables instead of 5 general integers.
Reads 3 doubles, violating the requirement for 5 integers. The variable names confirm the unrelated topic.

evidence.snippet: System.out.printf("The average acceleration is %s", (v1 - v0) / t);
evidence.note: Performs an acceleration calculation, demonstrating the core logic of the correct problem (sum of even numbers) is missing.

misconceptions.name: Solving the wrong problem
misconceptions.description: The student has submitted code that solves a completely different problem (acceleration calculation) instead of the assigned problem (sum of even numbers). This indicates a fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they should write a program to calculate average acceleration from velocity and time values.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading 5 integers from the user and calculating the sum of only the even numbers among them.
symptoms: Code reads 3 double values (v0, v1, t) instead of 5 integers
Code calculates acceleration (v1 - v0) / t instead of summing even numbers
Output displays acceleration formula result instead of sum of even numbers
No loop structure to process 5 inputs
No conditional logic to check if numbers are even
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either worked on the wrong assignment, copied code from a different problem, or fundamentally misread the problem statement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem carefully. The task is to: (1) read exactly 5 integers, (2) check which ones are even using the condition n % 2 == 0, (3) accumulate their sum, (4) print the result. Start fresh with the correct problem in mind.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The submitted code solves an entirely different problem with no overlap to the assigned task. The class name (AccelerationCalculator), variable names (v0, v1, t), formula, and logic all point to an acceleration calculation, not sum of even numbers.

evidence.note: Entire program solves acceleration calculation instead of sum of even numbers. Reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers, calculates (v1-v0)/t instead of filtering even numbers and summing them.

misconceptions.name: Solved a different problem than the one assigned
misconceptions.description: The program is designed to compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of reading five integers and summing the even ones, indicating a misunderstanding or disregard of the given problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the task is to read v0, v1, and t and compute the average acceleration ( (v1 - v0) / t ) rather than to sum the even numbers among five provided integers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program must read exactly five integers from the user, use a loop to process them, check each number with n % 2 == 0 to determine if it is even, and accumulate and print the sum of only the even numbers.
symptoms: Prompt text asks for 'Enter v0, v1, and t:' instead of 'Enter 5 integers:' or similar.
The code reads three double values instead of five integers.
The computation performed is (v1 - v0) / t, not a sum of selected inputs.
No loop, no evenness test, and no accumulator for a sum are present.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely copied from or based on a different textbook/example problem (average acceleration) or misread the assignment instructions, leading to implementing an unrelated specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the assignment carefully and restate the requirements in your own words before coding. Design an algorithm specifically for this problem: 1) initialize sum to 0, 2) use a loop to read 5 integers, 3) if a number is even (n % 2 == 0), add it to sum, 4) after the loop, print the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (prompt text, variable names, and formula) aligns with an average-acceleration example rather than the required sum-of-even-numbers task.

evidence.note: The code clearly implements an average acceleration calculation using three doubles and never attempts to read five integers, check for even numbers, or sum them.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misunderstanding of Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for calculating average acceleration (a different conceptual problem) instead of the required task of summing even numbers from 5 inputs.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have copied or written code for a different assignment (possibly Q2 or a previous lab exercise) and submitted it for Q1, indicating a complete failure to address the stated requirements.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read five separate integer inputs and use conditional logic to determine which ones are even (n % 2 == 0) and accumulate their sum.
symptoms: Code calculates acceleration using v0, v1, and t.
Input prompt requests variables unrelated to the required sum of evens.
Reads 3 double inputs instead of 5 integer inputs.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpreting which assignment text corresponds to which submission slot, or fundamental failure to read and follow the instructions for Q1.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the specific requirements for Q1: Sum of Even Numbers. Ensure the program reads 5 integers, uses a loop, checks for evenness, and sums the results.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code addresses a completely different, unrelated physics problem (acceleration calculation) from the requested task (sum of even numbers).

evidence.note: The class name itself is completely unrelated to the 'Sum of Even Numbers' task.
Indicates the calculation of acceleration, not the summation of integers.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Data Type for Input
misconceptions.description: The requirement was to read 5 integers, but the student read 3 double values.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student used `double` inputs, potentially failing to differentiate between integer and floating-point types, or because the variables `v0`, `v1`, and `t` inherently require doubles in the unintended acceleration problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task explicitly requires `integers`. Inputs should be read using `input.nextInt()`.
symptoms: Use of `input.nextDouble()` instead of `input.nextInt()`.
misconceptions.root_cause: Lack of attention to the required data type (integer), or confusion caused by implementing the wrong program which required doubles.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: When the problem specifies whole numbers, use the `int` data type (and `nextInt()`).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student explicitly called `nextDouble()` multiple times when `int` was required by the problem statement.

evidence.note: Reads a double and stores it in a double variable, contradicting the requirement for integers.

misconceptions.name: Problem Misinterpretation - Wrong Assignment Submitted
misconceptions.description: The student has submitted a solution for a completely different problem. The code calculates acceleration given two velocities and time, rather than summing even numbers from 5 user inputs. This indicates a fundamental misunderstanding or misreading of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the assignment requires calculating acceleration using the formula (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading 5 integers from the user, identifying which ones are even (using the condition n % 2 == 0), and printing their sum. The sample input/output clearly shows: Input: 3 8 2 7 4 → Output: Sum of even numbers: 14 (because 8 + 2 + 4 = 14).
symptoms: Code calculates acceleration instead of sum of even numbers
Reads 3 double values instead of 5 integers
No loop structure for processing multiple inputs
No even/odd checking logic
No accumulator for summing values
Variable names (v0, v1, t) are irrelevant to the problem
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either submitted code from a different assignment by mistake, misread the problem statement, or confused this assignment with another one (possibly a physics problem about acceleration).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the problem statement. The task is to sum even numbers, not calculate acceleration. Start fresh: (1) Create a loop to read 5 integers, (2) Use modulo (%) to check if each number is even, (3) Accumulate a sum of only the even numbers, (4) Print the final sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is unambiguously solving a different problem. No component of the submitted solution addresses the requirements of Q1 (sum of even numbers). This is not a minor logic error but a fundamental mismatch between the assignment and the submission.

evidence.note: Entire submission solves an acceleration problem rather than the sum-of-even-numbers problem. Class name 'AccelerationCalculator' further confirms this is the wrong solution.
Prompt requests v0, v1, and t (physics variables) instead of 5 integers as specified in the problem.

evidence.snippet: System.out.printf("The average acceleration is %s", (v1 - v0) / t);
evidence.note: Output calculates and displays acceleration, not the sum of even numbers required by Q1.
